only taught me that, if visiting it is to be of use to anyone with a specific purpose in mind, one must, apart from the most prominent and generally admired objects, turn away completely from the superfluity of what is there and limit oneself only to what can serve this purpose to the greatest extent possible, and that is why I only note, in these leisure hours and later, those things that particularly interested me, as I write first and foremost only for myself, knowing that my family and few friends will gladly make do with what is sufficient for myself. These pages are, as usual, only an account I give myself for the purpose of recollection.

In view of my limited leisure time, I devoted my attention almost exclusively to the mineral, and, in conjunction with these, metallurgical objects and their processing, as well as the machines and tools available for this purpose. As a result, the notes I took there and then, which constitute the synopsis in hand, were unfortunately almost too brief and catalogue-like to be instructive or engaging for anyone but myself by way of recollection.

SpecimensErratum from the first edition. of plumbago from the Borrowdale pit in Cumberland, this curious mineral, which in the great heat of our
smelting furnaces, when pulverised, does not even agglutinate, are the richest in carbon, the analysis yielding 90 parts in 100, and only the 10 remaining parts consist of silicon and iron oxide, interested me as crucible material, as well as various specimens of hydraulic lime or Roman cement, of which the basic constituents are as a rule always silicon, alum, lime, magnesia, siderite and soda. I passed by the hard coal samples of all kinds and sizes only with regret, as the various and weak veins in our canton (we cannot even apply the term "coal field") only seem to tantalise, and even to date in the whole of Switzerland, which seems to be situated at too high an altitude for a coal field, though they also occur in England not far from Ashford in a tunnel 300 feet above the sea. Cut into standard sized pieces, Stavely coals are said to be twice as useful both as fuel and as ship's ballast, since they leave no empty spaces between them when loaded.

Samples of artificial fuel, meaning solid lumps produced by strong pressure and mixed with tar from coal residue and the like, can be put on a par with so-called Russian carboline, and under certain circumstances can be regarded as a worthwhile product. Whether or not coals prepared from tanbark bricks are worthy of interest can only be determined by use and
comparison of their effect with other fuel, just as little can be said about the various types of iron ores, the majority of which belong to the clay ironstones and the hematites, the latter of which are added to the former, as they are poorer in content, to improve yield. Steel samples from the Ulverstone Ironworks and cutlery made from this steel, made by direct smelting of iron ore (red bloodstone, which is very fine in the quarry, something not entirely desirable), interested me very greatly. Finely ground samples of this ore, with which they carburise cast iron in England, are also on display here. This is nothing new, however; to date, the product has always been unreliable when produced in an open fire of any kind. To be done successfully, the only reliable method for this procedure is in the crucible; however, only very rich iron ores, yielding 60 to 70 pCt.Abbreviation for percent (%)., are suitable for this. We have such ores in Switzerland, in Bella Luna, but, to my knowledge, they do not occur in England. The model of a blast furnace, the throat of which is closed after each charge with a valve-like lid, and the flame emitted through a side furnace to be used for special purposes, was also not without interest to me. However, I was not able
to learn anything of the results obtained with it.

The large silver cake, weighing just over 7½ Centner and worth fl. 40,000, obtained using Mr. Pattinson's process, is remarkable for its size and the manner in which it was displayed. By means of a segregation process, or rather skimming off the still liquid lead with a perforated shovel from the silver that has already solidified in the melting pot, it is melted again in a reverberatory furnace, and the residual lead is oxidised (a kind of abrasion process), leaving silver of great purity.

I spent some time examining the various iron and alloy samples by Stirling and Morris. I first need to know more about their success in application before I will comment on their merits or shortcomings.

Their patented so-called “Patenttoughened" ironErratum from the first edition. consists of puddled iron into which, while still liquid in the furnace, chunks of wrought iron are thrown in – a product, which owing to the insufficient fusion, as the latter chunks do not turn into liquid, could only be extolled as excellent by a patent-addicted Englishman.

Malleable bell metal is ludicrous. Bells are cast, not forged. It is well known that the hardest bell metal
always produces the most beautiful tone. Their union metal appears to be a mixture of six parts cast iron and one part tin, which, if not invented by Rinnmann, was first described by him in his history of iron. In the samples of copper-iron compound there is evidence of free iron that has separated from the copper, which happens very easily if the proper techniques are not carefully practiced.

After lunch on this leisurely Sunday, I walked from my lodging, not always in the mood to write, from Ludgate Hill, partly as a shortcut, but primarily out of curiosity, through the narrow, crooked side streets to Blackfriars Bridge to observe life and the hustle and bustle on the Thames. Good God, I thought, whoever is condemned to spend his life in these dingy black buildings in the middle of the city, as it were, with their sparse, dusty windows and dark, cheerless rooms, must have grown accustomed to them from his youth. Only the conveniences to be found within the least of them offer some little compensation. Bread, meat, beer, milk and coal are brought into the house. Water is in the kitchen and light in the room, for, to produce light, gas flows out of the pipe as soon as a valve is turned and ignites with a small bang when a burning piece of paper is held up to it.
One needs neither lamp nor wick trimmer, though the gas flame does blacken, and everything in these dwellings is so dark and gloomy that one is glad only to see the open sky again and be out in the fresh air again.

Having arrived on Blackfriars Bridge, I could not without repeated astonishment, though I had seen it before but not to such a degree, contemplate the number of passenger steamers moving up and down every second of the day, as they are the real omnibuses on water. At one moment I counted 12 moving between Blackfriars and London Bridge alone and, on the whole, some 30 going up and down within a little less than an hour. What struck me, and it is likely the latest design, were the low and narrow smoke-free funnels on a few of them, while others were still emitting thick black clouds of it. These new boats were also not exceptionally long, but narrow, and cut across the bow and built with a very tight curvature. The speed of the wheels, and thus of the ship, was quite fast, which is easier to achieve with high-pressure steam engines than with atmosphericErratum from the first edition. ones. It is quite mind-boggling to think how the immense capital for everything one sees could have been raised.

Yet, it is more the circulation than the amount of money that is visible here. Each new generation inherits from the preceding one its debts and its money, then, generally speaking, continues its activity for 30 years before stepping down again from the stage to make room for a new one.

Anyone who has seen the cottages of the inhabitants of our northernmost regions can imagine at best, albeit without certainty, how it might have looked here nearly 2000 years ago, when Julius Caesar undertook his march to Britain, and not far from this place cut his pile bridge across the Thames (some of these piles were excavated about 50 years ago and preserved in the Leverian Museum, where I saw them. They are made of oak, but black through and through like ebony, and just as hard).

div.head: Fischer on the visit by the British seamen, 30 June 1851
div.p:
Monday, June 30th. Last week, at her expense, the Queen had her own sailors, namely those who are exclusively on duty on the two royal yachts, brought to the exhibition on a special train on the railroad from Spithead, where, if I am not mistaken, these ships are docked. They all appeared in their blue jackets, white "Trousers" and simple oilcloth hats with wide brims, very handsome, indeed. Many still adorned with cords for good behaviour. This seems to me an excellent idea to encourage emulation.
Corporals, sergeants and sergeant majors must be in every company, even if there is not an excellent man among them, and they have their badges of distinction, as is quite respectable. Medals are also awarded, especially in wartime, for special service, though it is not always wartime, in which case they seem to be appropriate for good conduct in peacetime, as well. The Queen's idea of making the exhibition accessible to her sailors has since been extended to other persons unable to visit the exhibition for reasons of duty, of their distance from London, or want of funds. Orphans and boys from seminaries have also been admitted, and today, while I was sitting at breakfast, there passed by my windows five wagons decorated with tree branches and flags, some of which were designed only for people to stand in so-called "Vans" and others for people to sit in, and each wagon drawn by four horses, all five of which could together hold well over 300 people. They were the workers from two factories. This example will now, for better or worse, have to be imitated by many others, which will significantly increase revenues for the exhibition. In the end, England always finds the greatest part of its resources in itself, for when one considers the costs of this undertaking, which have already been incurred
and are yet to be incurred, then what the foreigner contributes is, in fact, virtually nothing, for he can have his fill of the exhibition four days a week from 10 o'clock in the morning until 7 o'clock in the evening for 4 Shillings or 2 fl. 24 kr.

Before leaving for the exhibition on this foggy, mid-summer morning, I paid a visit to Mr. Mind in Oxford Street, who received me hospitably, and also introduced me to his wife and elder daughter, as his and his younger daughter's traveling companion from Dover to London. After that I headed to Mr. v. Buschek, Imperial Austrian Commissioner, at his office, 43 Clarges Street, Picadilly, in order to discuss important matters regarding the oversight in the catalogue concerning the exhibits of my son, Mr. Georg Fischer of Hainfeld.

div.head: Fischer's seventh visit, 1 July 1851
div.p: July 1st. In anticipation of soon leaving London, so that I might travel to the north of England before my journey home, I spent the whole day in the exhibition halls, where one can refresh oneself as necessary, without having to leave the building.

For myself, as well as for those who may get hold of this little manuscript some day, I will include the things that were most interesting to me today in pencil, comparing them with the suggestions in the synopsis, and then I will stop; after all, one can never really be finished.

Files, sickles and scythes with mostly
rivetedErratum from the first edition. handles are available from Sheffield in great quantity, as well as steel samples of all kinds, of which, however, I noticed a cast bar ("Ingot"), of which, as usual, the upper part was cold formed, but which also contained the bubbles (holes inside from gas that is not expelled or absorbed by means of additives), which they call "Piping", so common in English castings.

Also on display are stamps for medals, engraved in the usual way, but whose lower half contains either welded iron, or the whole cylinder or truncated cone in a ring of welded bar iron, proving how the English cast steel, as a result of its lower resistance to contraction during extinguishing and cooling in water, in comparison with several types of cast steel from the continent, tends to crack during hardening, as sadly demonstrated by the precious master stamp, made in English steel, of our Swiss V-franc coins, which had been so excellent in its intended conception and design.

The beauty of the Berlin cast-iron wares, which in my opinion are produced most exquisitely in Vienna, also evoked much enthusiasm here. This was magnified by the completed masterpiece of the Bavarian lion in bronze, which enabled those who had not enjoyed the great pleasure of seeing the colossal statue of the Bavaria
for themselves in the beauty of its form and the art of its casting, to imagine what a magnificent monument of taste and art King Ludwig must have erected during his reign.

Returning to the subject of iron casting in Berlin, I note from my own experience that a small addition of English tin to the cast iron gives it a similar disposition to take on the finest contours of the mould when cast, as does the iron from phosphoric marsh ore, which, it is believed, is the preferred casting material in Berlin.

Because it is, to an extent, related to metallurgy, and inasmuch as these natural substances are used for photography, I mention a new improvement that has come about in that field, namely that the so-called negative paper (the paper which receives the first or reverse impression of the chemical light rays in the camera [the English never say camera obscura]) is now substituted by mat-ground glass plates, which, as is never mentioned, however, must, of course, be covered with a similar coating that is receptive or sensitive to light rays, as the so-called energiatype or photographic paper.
Also very interesting is a true silver plating of glass, instead of coating it with mercury and a tin foil.

Between the narrow space of two glass plates, the edges of which are held apart by wax strips, a neutral silver solution is poured in, and a little glucose is added, or even gun cotton dissolved in alkali, so that the shiny metallic silver is deposited on the glass plate. When the process is complete, the liquid part of the solution is poured off, the coating is rinsed with pure water, dried and protected against the effects of air by completely sealing it all around.

As an object of metal, I must also mention the great organ, since I went to see it being played, which happened frequently. It is 38 feet high, 26 feet wide and 23 feet deep and has 5000 pipes, of which the largest is 32 feet and the smallest not quite ½ inch long and has 80 keys. Incidentally, despite its size it does not occupy much space in these immense rooms. Even its sound, as powerful as it is, soon seems to fade away in the immense space.

div.head: Fischer's eighth visit, 2 July 1851
div.p:
July 2nd. The object that occupied my attention today, after I had consulted Mr. Cammel earlier, also belongs to the field to which I devote myself out of preference and partly as my own profession, though I find that I go further than I intended, namely, the specimen of zinc ore, almost granite-like in appearance, weighing 164 Centner, located near the eastern entrance of the transept or nave of the building,
if it can be so called, at the main entrance, which was found close to Earth's surface in "New-Yersey" in the United States of North America.

In fact, if one were to add up the weight of all the objects inside and outside the building, and then the weight of the building in iron, glass, and wood, it would seem as though the whole world could be balanced against it, and yet two years ago on May 1st there was not yet anything of the millions of Centner to which even our antipodians have contributed. Returning to the metals, Austria, as was to be expected, is first among the exhibitors from abroad, both in the number of its objects and their variety in iron, steel, scythes, sickles, all manner of tools, as well as manufacturing, which is represented by the products of my son Georg in cast steel and various files of cast steel, and then those of "malleable Castiron" and spindles by my youngest son Berthold, whereby I must also mention the very fine products of the Bohemian glassmaker's art, in which, as with the metals, pyrotechnics play a leading role, and before which I stood in amazement. Iron and steel productions, both unprocessed and processed, from my beloved fatherland of Switzerland are insignificant.
However, of great importance are the other products, namely spun cotton, ribbons and silk fabrics, weaving and embroidery, clay products of a higher quality ("terra cotta") by Mr. Ziegler-Pellis, and then watchmaking, wickerwork and woodcarving etc. Regrettably, nothing was to be found from the Escher Factory, which could have claimed so much attention for its achievements and before whose output its rivals in England would have had to bow. In vain, the electric clock in the centre of the transept admonished me to leave soon for home. Of its actual inner mechanism, I know nothing other than that its movement is caused by the alternating forces of magnetic attraction and repulsion and that it was, perhaps, inspired by the low-powered Zamboni pile. This, too, is a powerful voice hailing the advances of physics, in connection with chemistry and mechanics, in our present age.

I also looked at the copper ores of Burra-Burra in South Australia, which yield up to 70 pCt.Abbreviation for percent (%). of pure copper, as well as those from India, around which countries England equally wraps its tentacles. Its wealth is immeasurable, and yet it has so many poor and miserable people there, not to speak of Irland, where starvation has become a common occurrence. My every thought is of leaving and, yet, as if in some an enchanted castle, I cannot find my way out.
I also went to see the fire pump engine from Canada — a device of which I have made and repaired so many in my lifetime. Its effectiveness is said to be tremendous and hitherto unknown. Since I could not see its inner workings, nor was it indicated how many men were required to operate it*), it is impossible to calculate whether the information about its effectiveness is accurate. Incidentally, the principle remains forever true that a machine, by and large, only approximates the applied force, and beyond that nothing more can be contrived. However, it is a different matter when the available force is properly distributed to serve different purposes in one and the same machine, whereby, among those actually in operation at the exhibition, I count as one of the most remarkable, one wherein raw cotton is passed from one location to another to be spun immediately, through the artful combination of working parts, into fine yarn. This yarn is threaded onto the weaving machine ("powerloom") and, after being crossed in the "flying shuttle (navette volante"), threaded and threaded again, comes out at the opposite end of the machine as a finished piece of cotton fabric.Since writing this, I have learned that 40 men are required for this. How all of them can use the moment of force to which they are exposed is beyond me.

I also looked for the second time at the great hydraulic press, this beautiful invention of the master locksmith Bramah, who lived at the time I was working in London in 1794. It was used to lift the pieces of enormous pipes, weighing 42,000 Centner each and that formed the route for the railroad between the mainland and the Island of Anglesia, up to the tower-like nearly 109-foot-high stone edifice.

div.head: London–Birmingham, 3 July 1851
div.p:
July 3rd. At last, thank God! I have finally escaped the tedium of London, having sent Mr. Cammel, who yesterday gave me a coloured lithographic drawing of his extraordinarily large steelworks in Sheffield, a similar one of my modest steel foundry in Mühlenthal near Schaffhausen, and left at 11 o'clock in the morning for Euston station ("Terminus"), which is nearly four miles from my lodging, to go from there by rail to Birmingham, which is 112 English miles from London. At quarter past 12 o'clock, the train left. The second-class fare was 15 Shilling or 9 fl. I appreciated the arrangement that one's suitcase and night bag, provided the former is not too large, are given to the passenger in his compartment and pushed under the bench, which has sufficient space for them. It relieves one of all worries in that regard:
for in England, no numbers are attached to the items as in Germany, as nothing is weighed, nor any payment required. I arrived in Birmingham precisely at 5 o'clock, stopped at the Stork Hotel, which seems a very good inn, and after lunch and reading the newspapers, took another tour through the streets. I first stood still at a caricature shop, in front of a caricature that ruthlessly ridiculed the Catholic Archbishop Wisemann and Lord Brougham, who had spoken somewhat in his favour in the House of Lords.

The slightest step too far by Wisemann would awaken as yet apparently sleeping British lions, whose claws have something to say. — I was astonished when I visited Mr. Poole, whom I had known from before, at the patent office to bring him a greeting from Mr. Kreeft and was asked by his fellow clerk whether I and Mr. Kreeft were Protestants or Catholics? Let it not be said that tolerance is generally at home in England, for my business had as little to do with any religious creed as with the man in the moon. It is curious how long political and religious partisanship can remain dormant and then be ignited again by the slightest spark. In that bookstore, there were also scores of French
playing cards lying by the window in an unusually small format. Out of curiosity I enquired about the price, and it was "a halfpenny" or 1½ Kreuzer of our money. I purchased one to assure myself that I had heard correctly. Next door was a bookbinder's shop, where charming Bibles beautifully bound in black Saffian with gilded edges were displayed in the window. I had no need to ask the price, there were slips of paper (as is often the case in England with all kinds of merchandise, as they frown upon all manner of questions and answers) for "1 Shilling and two Pence", or 42 Kreuzer of our money. These two things, playing cards and the Bible, indeed did not belong together, and anyone who knows me can well believe that I am not making light of this. However, I immediately acquired this beautiful edition, although it lacks what I found with surprise in older English Bibles among the apocryphal books and, in my opinion, precisely the best, namely the Book of Sirach. More, neither Lord Chesterfield's Letters to his Son, nor Knigge's book on human intercourse, nor Kampe's Theophron are part of this excellent work, neither in deep knowledge of human nature, nor in practical wisdom, nor in high piety, while the Book of Solomon — in England, "Song" — has found acceptance and been forced by the theologians into a dialogue between Christ and the Church.
I once conversed with an unmarried Englishwoman, who was a Pietist, on this subject, and she too was very much enamoured of the Song of Solomon, but could say nothing about the Book of Sirach, of which she had never heard. Since that time, I have asked myself more than once whether the first publisher of the Bible in the English language might well have had a wicked wife to whom, by including this work among the apocrypha, he would have held up a mirror with a rather unflattering reflection.

A mere three paces from the bookbinder's shop was an ironmonger, or rather, half and half, quincaillerie, and at the window medals of lovely white metal, bearing a likeness of the Crystal Palace. What does such a medal cost (in size of a standard florin), I asked the gentleman in the store, and behold, the price, which was scarcely to be believed, was 1½ Kreuzer or "a half penny". I took several of them. There were also artificial magnets hanging from the window. I purchased one of not insignificant strength, five inches long, including the anchor, and what did I pay for it? Answer: 18 Kreuzer ("six pence"). It is very nicely made, and what is very understandable, covered down to the anchor with reddish varnish. Only in Birmingham is it possible to buy such metal wares for so ridiculous a price.

I stayed with this very knowledgeable man,
whose shop is well visited, until it grew dark and told him, as I took my leave, that I would return the following day.

div.head: Birmingham, 4 July 1851
div.p:
July 4th. As I had promised, I returned to him first thing next day and brought him a sample of my copper-iron compound. He was very surprised by its red colour and by the fact that the metal mixture was so readily attracted by the magnet and, walking ahead of me, beckoned me to follow. After climbing a long, narrow staircase, we came to two of his storerooms, which were neatly arranged, and then he led me to an attic ("Garret"), where he showed me something that I had really never seen before. Namely, a rolling mill with rollers 2½ feet long and positioned one above the other, at one end of which there was a crank, and at the axles near the pivot bearings there were two spur gears of equal size, which interlocked with each other, and then a third parallel roller, which, however, could be positioned higher or lower than one or the other axis of the rollers positioned one on top of the other by adjusting screws, as well as closer or further away from them. When a sheet of metal was placed between the first pair of rollers, it was pressed against the third roller by rotating the two rollers and rounded in this ratio to form an almost confluent cylinder once the sheet
had passed through its entire length, so that if it was made of tinplate, it only needed to be overlapped and soldered together by hand, and if it was made of iron, it needed only to be crimped. The cylinders were perfectly round and smooth and made with an immense saving of time. After some further conversation, all at once, he put on his black frock coat and said that I should accompany him to one of his friends, who had coin presses and drop presses and would be delighted to converse with me about stamping. So, we did, and Mr. Ralph Heaton, after we had discussed his manufacture, complained terribly about the coin punch he must use, adding that he could not get any steel in Birmingham that was suitable for it and, thus, had to have it sent from London. He showed me pieces that were partly cracked during hardening and partly with holes and unevenly hardened spots that appeared when they were milled. After inspecting them, I asked if he was minting currency; he led me down a flight of stairs into a kind of cellar, where, in a very narrow space beneath two large presses, each attended by a young boy, money was being minted at great speed by the six-horsepower, high-pressure steam engine, just as Mr. Watt in Soho had set it up at the mint in London. I thought at first they were medallions, only he said: No, it is money. I am minting for the Republic of Chilé in South America. And no one
has stood in his way. It is really very pretty copper money, having a diameter of \frac{13}{16} English inches, and an apparent thickness of not quite \frac{1}{12} inch, I say apparent because the rim protrudes on both sides. — It is valued at exactly "½ Penny" of English currency, which is 1½ Kreuzer of Reichsgeld. As soon as I have the opportunity, I will investigate how many of our oh so delightful Swiss cents go into such a coin, about which, regarding forgery, was warned in vain by those who have acquired some knowledge and experience in the metallurgical field, contrary to the conceit of those who believe that with tales and hollow phrases everything is remedied, not to mention the fact that we still sent the money abroad to be manufactured, while our own mints in Switzerland, indeed, I argue those in Bern alone, would have sufficed to meet the demand. For it must be known that each of these two presses supplied 30,000, I repeat, thirty thousand pieces per day.

This really beautiful money had, as the figure shows, on its obverse a pentagonal
star and the inscription: Republica de Chilé, 1851, and on its reverse a laurel wreath, in the middle of which are the words: un Centavo, and outside the wreath the motto: Economia Es Riqueza. Not only did this man, whom I had never seen before in my life, show me all of his equipment, including 4 drop presses, under which one presses the beautiful thin brass objects, which are then covered with gold varnish, but he also entrusted me with six pieces of this newly minted money. He hardened all of his coins, as he showed me, under running water, as is necessary for hard steel. He explained that if he were to immerse them at once in water, they would all crack. — As I departed from him, I thought to myself, "There is not a corner of the earth that does not avail itself of the craftsmanship and artistry of the English. Chilé sends its precious metals to England, and they send copper money in return." — I lunched with one of the Weiss brothers, to whom I had been referred by my friend Mr. Escher in Zurich, in an establishment where there is a table d'hôte of about 20 customers a day.

— I expressed a wish to visit the once famous Soho, where in 1814 Mr. WaltThe person meant is probably Mr. Watt, i.e. James Watt the Younger., then owner of this factory, had shown me so much friendship. I thus arranged for a "Cab", and Mr. Weiss was good enough to accompany me. He informed me at the outset
that this great machine factory had fallen into decline since the death of Mr. Watt and his associate, Mr. Boulton, whom I also knew very well. When we arrived, there was not a soul on the premises. Everything in the numerous workshops was empty and desolate. Much of it was in a state of decay. What a difference! to when I first saw this establishment at the height of its splendour and the owners enjoyed such income as not even every prince has. I could never have imagined such a rapid transformation had I not seen it with my own eyes. This place, more than many others, would be worthy of the inscription "Sic transit gloria mundi"Latin for "Thus passes the glory of the world.".

Having returned from Soho and taken leave of my two compatriots (Messrs. Weiss are from Winterthur), I purchased a very good spring balance with which one can weigh up to 45 Pf., for 1 Shilling or 36 Kr. and then proceeded to my lodging to record the events of this day.

div.head: Birmingham–Manchester, 5 July 1851
div.p: Saturday, July 5th. At 10 o'clock, I left Birmingham for Manchester. The journey should have been completed in 3½ hours for the 80 miles, however, for unknown reasons the "Train" stopped at Stockport for an entire hour and then at another place for half an hour, so that we did not arrive in Manchester until after 3 o'clock.

How this place has grown in size since I was here in 1827, one can scarcely imagine
without seeing it. Miles of straight and wide streets now define this enterprising city, which owes its present size and prosperity to the invention of a humble barber, Arkwright, who first conceived the idea of spinning cotton by machinery, and the execution of which idea was undertaken by his brother-in-law, a carpenter, with the metal parts made by founders and locksmiths. The first cylinders were made only of brass, and for each thread there was a single piece about one inch long. We were still making such things when I worked for Mr. Rhé, a mechanic in London, in 1794. The patent he obtained for his invention, which was immediately seized upon by the practical spirit of the English, he sold, as Mr. Watt told me some 38 years ago, for such large sums that he obtained an annual income of 10,000 pounds sterling, or fl. 120,000.

Like Birmingham, Manchester, too, is enveloped in a perpetual cloud of smoke. The only difference being that, in the former, only tall chimneys protrude from it, emitting flames from time to time, while in the latter, one also occasionally sees the spinning mills, 6 to 7 stories high, with their infinite number of windows. These are otherwise quite rare in English private homes, so that in many of their myrmidonian dwellings, per floor, of which there are rarely three, only one mullioned,
"Sashwindow" of three feet in width is to be seen. One might ask, then, how does light enter these structures? However, the English are no fools and, like Paxton in his glass palace, let the light in at the top of the roof, a feature that I believe is not missing from virtually any house. In general, the English architectural style, in this respect, is strange and tasteless. Compare such a house, which looks like a large, partly red and partly black-brown brick, with our friendly farmhouses in various cantons of Switzerland, and especially in the canton of Zurich, and make your own judgment.

After a short lunch, I decided to visit my old acquaintance, Mr. Fairbairn, who has a large enterprise for steamboats and steam engines, but I did not encounter him at the factory. I proceeded to his residence nearly three miles from there, to which a very wide new road led. Here, the, I would like to say ridiculous, Rococo taste, which has displaced all noble forms and turned everything that exists in this style to eternal dust and cobweb traps, is now visible on the gables of a long row of houses, which are turned at a very acute angle to the street, as now and then in the old imperial cities, and are elaborated with all
manner of flourishes on the overhanging beams and bows or struts.

Many people often do not know what they want, either out of wantonness or laziness. While the French talk too much, the English talk too little, and that is often the source of their eccentric thoughts. Still, in the end, I would rather stick with the English than with vacuous palaver and whimsy.

I did not meet Mr. Fairbairn himself, who is presently at a scientific convention in Ipswich and will return to London on Tuesday. His sonFairbairn had four sons: Thomas, George, Peter and John. Fischer probably means Thomas Fairbairn (1823–1891), who was his father's partner for many years., with whom I had a very pleasant conversation, gave me his address, so that on my return from Sheffield I may well have the pleasure of seeing my old friend there, whose name is well known throughout England.

I must add with regard to Birmingham how immensely well satisfied I was there at the Stork Hotel. Everything, without exception, was better and nicer than in my lodging in London, and at least a third less expensive. In the English countryside, one is delightfully comfortable, but not so in London.

div.head: Manchester–Sheffield, 6 July 1851
div.p:
Sunday, July 6th. After breakfast (half past nine) I went through and arranged my papers, wrote instructions for two of my sonsHe is referring to Wilhelm Fischer (1803—1882) and Georg Fischer (1804—1888). in Austria, who also intend to visit England, and packed my things, as the "Train" to Sheffield was leaving at 3 o'clock,
and I wanted to have lunch beforehand. The journey in second class, which cost 9 Sh. and 6 pence, or 3 fl. 18 kr. of our money, for the 40 miles, was tedious owing to frequent stops, but interesting on account of the astonishingly varied, hilly country, similar to that around Liège, where, after passing through a long and densely dark tunnel, one suddenly rolls along over a viaduct (railroad track constructed on piers and arches), which is often at first much higher than the houses standing adjacent to it. A journey with such variety in the construction of railroads might appear quite enticing to us Swiss, as in our beloved fatherland we have plenty of physical-geographical (as well as political) ups and downs. But heaven forbid that we should take on, at least for the time being, a project for a new railway system at the expense of the state: it would bring us ten times the duplicitous blessing of the new coin. — One must have travelled many hundreds of miles, on railways in various countries, to obtain a reasonably clear understanding of the advantages and disadvantages. We are not a monarchical state. Due to their size in commercial terms, and then due to their neighbours, and as recent times have shown, due to potential domestic political events, monarchical states are compelled to do so. England, least of all, is to be
taken as a model and pretext for the construction of railways, for even in this country, so rich in industry and population and better equipped than any other in Europe with the means to build them cheaply, some railways have been built that did not bring the kind of return believed possible, though they are otherwise quite reliable here in their calculations. One truth is certain: first of all, that for most of our planned railways there is no absolute necessity, and the temporary delay will and can cause far less damage than haste, of which one has already received clear indications in Schaffhausen and elsewhere in all manner of cases, especially in political relations. Secondly, one more truth is certain: that with the immense progress of our age, in physics, chemistry and mechanics, as well as in the technology elevated and supported by these sciences, it is not only probable, but one may say certain, that also the means of transportation, in one way or another, perhaps within a very short time, will be greatly advanced. When battle was fought with bow and arrow as long-range weapons, no one had the faintest idea of a battery of twenty-four-pounders and their effect. Once, in our country and elsewhere, innocent witches were burned to death for flying for their own amusement on their broomsticks through the air to
Bloksberg on Walpurgis night and, now, the aeronauts soar, unmolested, over land and sea. Not to speak of the speediness of the locomotive and the lightning speed of the electric telegraph. If someone, inspired by Athena's spirit, had foretold at the time these phenomena in their present manifestation, he would have been sent to heaven knows where! But enough of this.

div.head: Fischer's business visits in Sheffield, 7 July 1851
div.p:
July 7th. This morning my first outing in Sheffield was to Messrs. Rodgers and Sons, the most illustrious manufacturers of cutlery and plated goods, not only in this city but, one may say, in all of England, and brought them some razors of the meteor steel I had invented to obtain their opinion of its quality, with the request that I should be able to pick them up again tomorrow, which they promised me. Leaving there, I paid a visit to the cast steel factory of Mr. Johnson, Cammel and Comp, in which, according to Mr. Cammel, 1000 Centner of cast steel and cement steel are produced weekly, as already mentioned, which is perfectly comprehensible when one sees the extent of the workshops, which are now being increased by a large new building, and when one considers the immense number of locomotive, "Train" and other types of carriage springs, which, as Mr. Kreeft
informed me, are ordered from them by the large railroad companies on a regular basis. In general, they seek their advantage in the quantity of production, which, with their product, is possible by selling, as I have been told, a pound of such spring steel for 2½ pence, or 7 Kreuzer of our money. They re-acquire the old or otherwise broken springs for a much lower price, making partly cast steel and partly new springs out of it. With such a substantial reduction in the price of coal and coke, which is close to 30 pCt.Abbreviation for percent (%). compared to what it was 4 years ago when I was in England and visited their factory, and since the cost of fuel in their highly efficient bloomeries is so low, it is possible to achieve such a low price.

However, it seems to me that they do not do as high-quality work as Turton & Sons, who also make blister steel, cast steel and welded steel, and from the latter, springs. Mr. JohnsonIt is not clear whether Thomas or Henry Johnson is meant. had a new spring tested in my presence, which, however, broke long before it had reached its maximum extension through straight compression. In general, since the three gentlemen who make up this company, the third being a German, Gosse, brother-in-law of Mr. Cammell, spend more time in the office than in the workshops and, therefore, require a "Foreman" for each of their industrial fields, the quality of
such a foreman is astonishingly decisive. Mr. Johnson sent for the smelter, and so we went into one of the smelting houses, where 24 furnaces were in continual operation in this one alone and casting took place at all times, since each furnace smelts three times a day. Here, too, as has happened elsewhere, I was asked first by Mr. Johnson and then by the smelting foreman, in particular, how the piping (that is, the gas formation when the steel is poured, and the gas, which remains, adheres, or develops only in the moment of pouring, creates holes of various sizes inside the steel, while no trace of it is noticeable from the outside on the poured bar or the poured object in general) is prevented, whereupon I found it appropriate to simply tell him that "this depends on the conduct of the melting process." He also asked me a question, which appeared to be very simple, but which made me realise at once that he merely sought to determine through this manoeuvre the extent of my experience ("pump me out"). I had no desire for this type of catechism, however, and soon afterward took my leave of these gentlemen, as it was time for lunch.

In the afternoon, I went first to Mr. Huntsman's hammer mill, where I was well known to the hammer smiths through Mr. Huntsmann himself, and again inspected the facilities
there for heating furnaces and welding ovens. The smaller furnace is heated with coke, the larger one with hard coal, and a bellow is used. These fires are far superior to our charcoal-fired forges. Mr. Huntsman himself was, again, unfortunately out of town, and so I continued on from the Don River to West Street to the steel foundry of my old friend Mr. Charles Sanderson, where I was sorry to hear that he was suffering from podagricPodagra, gout in the foot, especially the big toe. and chiragricChiragra, gout in the joints of the hands and fingers. pains, as was the case four years ago, but that he was not bedridden. I now had to contend with a walk almost a mile to his home, which did not prevent me from visiting him. He received me with great kindness into his home, where his wife promptly invited me to stay for tea, which I accepted with great pleasure, being parched with thirst and feeling unwell myself. Our general conversation, as she is a very intelligent and agreeable woman, revolved for a long while around the exhibition. It is, at present, the favourite subject of the English, forming the morning and evening entertainment with visitors from abroad, and, indeed, one can hardly blame them for this miracle, which so suddenly unfolded before the inhabitants of our globe.

Mr. Sanderson afforded me great pleasure by promising, since he has considerable experience in this field, to provide me, as soon as his hand
is usable again, with an accurate report, which I have long awaited, on the minimum of coke required to make from our bean ores, which he as a mineralogist knows very well, the grey, carbonised pig iron suitable for cupola furnaces, and to enclose a drawing by his own hand for a blast furnace in such small dimensions as the nature of the matter allows.

We also spoke of a blast furnace, a model of which is at the exhibition, that is closed at the top by a valve opened only for filling the throat with coal and ores, etc., and then immediately closed again, where the flame and gases are directed sideways through closed tubes for use in other purposes. This furnace has three nozzles, like Wilkinson's furnaces, which is certainly the best that can be had. Mr. Sanderson, however, had not yet seen it, owing to his indisposition. I also made mention of another far larger model of a blast furnace at the exhibition, with six nozzles, which is probably too many, as it weakens the lining and mantle excessively. More than 50 years ago, von Reden, Minister of Mines, built such a blast furnace in the Harz region, with six nozzles, which offered no greater advantage than is obtained with three.

After conversing for nearly two hours, I departed from this family, which has always shown me great friendship, with the wish that they would also visit me soon in Switzerland,
and I ended this long day by writing in my diary.

div.head: Further business visits in Sheffield, 8 July 1851
div.p: On July 8th, I visited the cast steel manufacturers, Messrs. Turton and Sons, with whom I am also on friendly terms, and who, in addition to a very large volume of files, also produce a lot of springs for railroad cars. The demand for this product is unbelievable! Their springs appeared to me better than Cammel's. These gentlemen do their own work, and the specimens I was shown stood up perfectly to rigorous testing. As the saying goes, "It's the eye of the master that fattens the horse".

Mr. Turton was not at the foundry in Bow Spring, but at the place where they have their rolling mills and hammers, at what is called the Sheaf works, not far from the Don River, which powers the Huntsman's hammer mill. I never expected to discover such an extensive mill. The number of workshops, including grinders, hammer mills, file smithies, tool smiths, etc., amounts to 73, according to the numbers written on the doors. Several of the offices are staffed by officials.

Mr. Turton was preparing to leave for London to visit his brother, who was very ill, and, as he passed by, told the "Porter", and no proper factory in England is without one, allow this gentleman, pointing to me, to come and visit
all the workshops as he pleases. He accompanied me to my lodging, where I proceeded to lunch and he to the "Terminus" (train station) for his journey to London. In the afternoon I availed myself of his permission by first visiting the hammer mill. The stroke of the hammers is short but very fast, which makes sense, as the heat from the stroke always keeps the steel hot longer under a fast hammer blow than under a slow one, where the hammer is heavier and the stroke longer. Hammers and anvils are fitted with inserted “crosses” or hammer faces of "chilld" cast iron. Their drawing furnace did not seem to me as good as Huntsmann's, inasmuch as the coal and coke they burned did not reach the same high degree of ignition as there. I had hoped to go to the "Potterworks", after having made another tour of the rolling mill, but being too tired and the hour too late for such a long walk, I contented myself with writing my notes on the day.

div.head: Sheffield–Dover, 9 July 1851
div.p:
July 9th. Having finished my business, which could not have induced me to stay longer in any case due to my malaise, I went this morning to the cutlery and plated goods manufacturers Rodgers & Sons to retrieve my razors. They provided material for an interesting conversation with one of these gentlemen about the nature of iron in itself, as well as the
components of steel, and I valued the fact that we both agreed in the opinion that iron is actually only good if it is pure and that every purified iron can thank the manifold (in my experience, fourfold) substances, which are combined with it in flow or in strong and long-lasting annealing, for its becoming steel. He spoke very favourably about my razor blades and about the natural Damascus, the result of the displacement of the crystalsErratum from the first edition. in the flow of the molten steel. Time was running short. At 10 o'clock I was due at the train station, from where, after covering 165 miles, I arrived in London at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Once there, I called on Mr. Kreeft to discuss various matters with him. In the meantime, I was visited by Mr. Baird, who had returned from Schaffhausen, where he had assembled the ship delivered by Mr. Robinson, and in the evening at 6 o'clock I left for Dover, where I arrived after 9 o'clock, and left at 11 o'clock that night on the postal steamer for Ostend. If I compared the crossing from Ostend to Dover to a kind of hospice, then by morning I could have described the salon as a battlefield, for the weather was extremely stormy and seasickness had broken out among all the passengers, with the exception of one, who had likely completed long voyages at sea before.
Immediately on departure from Dover it was so crowded that, foreseeing what was to come, I went onto the deck, despite the storm and rain, borrowed an old blue jacket from a crewman for 6 pence, putting it on over my great coat and taking an old piece of sailcloth as a cover and a piece of rope rolled up in a coil as my pillow, and so in the vicinity of the steam engine on the bare deck took up my bed for the night, which was admittedly not a pleasant stay in the kind of weather I described, but which prevented me from contracting seasickness.

div.head: Ostend–Mannheim, 10-11 July 1851
div.p:
July 10th. As the day dawned, we saw the church tower of Ostend on the horizon, and I hoped that we would arrive there at 8 o'clock in the morning, according to the printed ticket, to leave as promised with the train to Cologne that was waiting for us, and therefore went down to the salon to fetch my overnight bag and umbrella, which I had left there, onto the deck. Oh, but what a spectacle! Passengers lying around on the floor and benches, afflicted with this disgusting disease and exhausted, overturned candlesticks on the tables from the swaying of the ship, broken bowls on the floor, soiled clothes, etc. As I said, everything was crowded, and I had to step on the feet of several people to fetch my belongings.
They drew back only mechanically, without saying a word. The ship was not able to enter Ostend until 10 o'clock in the morning, and so, instead of only four hours in the favourable case, we had needed eleven. I would never again recommend this crossing to anyone going to England or traveling from there to the mainland. Anyone wishing to travel to England should take the route, with Cologne as the end point of a journey along the Rhine, via Liège to Calais, and when coming from England, if he does not prefer to travel via Paris and Strassburg, from Calais back to Liège and Cologne. The morning train to Cologne did not wait for our ship, and so I could not leave Ostend until 1 o'clock that afternoon, and then took a night train from Aachen to Cologne, where I arrived early in the morning of July 11th and immediately continued my journey by rail to Mannheim, where I spent the night.

div.head: Mannheim–Freiburg–Schaffhausen, 12–14 July 1851
div.p: On July 12th, I arrived in Karlsruhe around noon, visited Mr. Kessler in the machine factory, and Currency Councillor Mr. Kachel in the mint, and took some orders. In the afternoon at 3 o'clock I left Karlsruhe again and was now able to spend another night in bed in Freiburg, as I had no bed for four nights in a row and was forced to spend one night in the open air and in bad weather.

On the 13th in the evening at 9 o'clock I departed from
Freiburg, and on the 14th in the morning at 10 o'clock, in spite of the hardships that this journey entailed, I arrived home again, thank God, healthy and happy.

div.head: Afterword: Thoughts on free trade
div.p: Postscript to my travel diaries.

If anyone other than my family and friends should get hold of this little volume and then ask why its publication, interest in whose contents may have been harmed by delay, has only now taken place, then let me answer very briefly that due to various official and personal business, it was only in November of this year that I was able to complete the copy of the original, which was written mostly in pencil. I would add that, because I wrote it for myself alone, I regard it merely as a picture of that period of my life and, yet, for that very reason, as can be the case with historical paintings on canvas, believe that one or another picture may retain some interest, for as long as the work takes to be published. — And now, in conclusion, the following remarks: while lunching in Sheffield, as the inn where I stayed has introduced a kind of table d'hôte on weekly market days, the principal conversation with my fellow lodgers revolved around free trade which was to be instituted and which was embraced by all with whom I spoke,
without exception. Reflecting on their arguments, and those I heard more particularly from various manufacturers, it became clear to me that only their own interest, they being by far the largest majority, made such a measure urgently desirable, a fact of which I became even more convinced when I considered their enormous factories and their profitability, and came to a conclusion as to the effect this freedom of trade, given such a superiority in technical and pecuniary means and the cheapness of their operating forces, would have, first, on my fatherland and then on other nations on the continent, as well.

On my way back, I pursued the matter even further. Only some time later, prompted by a newspaper article arguing to the contrary, I committed my views to paper and handed them over to the pressThe article appeared in two parts in the Tage-Blatt für den Kanton Schaffhausen, nos. 88 and 89, on 15 and 16 April 1852.. I now add them to these notes as well, as they pertain to my interestingErratum from the first edition. remarks in England, of which I made only fleeting and vague references on some of its pages.

For if one wishes to form an opinion on free trade, one must first consider what the duty of self-preservation demands of us, which is of greater importance and more closely related to us than all the spurious theories of freedom, equality and unanimity (the latter term was invented, for
one had to be embarrassed to speak of Swiss harmony), which are so hackneyed that not a grain more can be extracted from them, and after ascertaining the duties towards oneself, one has only to ask quite simply, what is free trade and what does it entail? The answer is, that every person may take the results of his labour, or of his commerce or trade, and sell them wherever he pleases, without being bound by any restriction favouring the labourers or merchants in the country where he takes his goods. Before the consequences of this freedom can be discussed, the question must be posed, Are the peoples of all nations where free trade is to be introduced on the same level of industry as a result of the natural products in their soil at the surface and in the depths of their earth? Or has nature, or have the social conditions and culture of mind based thereon, or to be more precise, the technical skill, created no difference? The answer, which arises from the existing and irrefutable facts, is no!

If then two nations, or, to bring the matter back to the simplest point, two manufacturers produce the same thing, but the one, through greater skill, supported by local advantages, can produce the needed objects, that is, all goods, in the same quality and, in most cases, even better than the other,
yet at a cheaper price, then one must know nothing of reality to believe that the consumers will not, in all cases, buy from the first and take no notice of the other, whereupon the latter gradually falls into ruin. Whether because he cannot contend with the competition as things stand and must therefore cease to produce, or whether, out of a sense of honour or obstinacy, he nevertheless continues in his occupation, he will just as surely become impoverished. However, one must not believe that this ruin affects him alone, no! In many thousand corollaries of human intercourse and sources of the circulation of money, which, despite our efforts of understanding remain as inscrutable as the thoughts of men, another vein is thereby cut off or clogged, which then, in turn, deprives others of their sustenance, at least in part, and it happens just as when one throws a stone into water, the rings continue to become apparently weaker but obtain greater circumference.

The principal question, however, is that which while relevant to the whole world, is to be considered here only specifically in relation to our fatherland. What reasons can England have to speak out in favour of the free trade system and to set in motion all levers, known and unknown, i.e., those of the press and the influences on individuals it has long successfully used to win others over to its interest, in order to achieve its objective?
The answer is simple, its interest and its interest alone — and one is very much mistaken to believe that, even if there are a few individuals of this nation who are distinguished by true liberality and magnanimity, there is not an equally developed and rigid egotism guiding its commercial policy, as with any other nation. History provides enough evidence of this, if the sulphur trade with Naples and the opium dispute with China are not proof enough.

Anyone looking through his own eyes, and not through the glasses of the theoretician from some attic window onto the continent, at this great work of the world exhibition of industry in London, which was almost beyond human strength to accomplish in the short period of time in which it was carried out, must admit, by all means, that the English manufacturers in general were allowed to measure themselves against any other similar products, and that anyone who was induced to purchase one thing and another, particularly in the factory towns, was able to see for himself that the English, with the exception of those products which nature denies to their climate and with the exception of very few objects insignificant as articles of world trade, produce everything satisfactorily and, generally, in even greater perfection than what could be imported from other countries.
This, in addition to the fact that the prejudice in favour of their own products, which generally prevails among them and is not entirely unfounded, makes them averse to the purchase of foreign products, if not for very special circumstances, such as uncommonly low prices, resulting from the cheapness of the raw materials at the site of the foreign producers, or unattainable perfection, where nature, especially in the case of dyed materials, as a result of the nature of the water or the atmosphere, favours other countries, cause the English to purchase these objects, which are quite insignificant in relation to their export.

div.head: The importance of free trade for England
div.p:
If we now further consider that the English produce in their country, by contrast, not only everything that human art and human genius can accomplish, so to speak, but that they, favoured by the spirit of perseverance, diligence and industriousness that pervades this nation, and by virtue of their vast experience, or, if you will, by virtue of their abundance of skilful people, of the great capital at their disposal and the tremendous driving force that the coal from the bosom of the earth enables them, produce in a given period of time a quantity sufficient for half the world, under which, in spite of all the advantages listed here, they would soon suffocate in no time, if they did not have an outlet to the outside world. Thus, it is clear to see why they so urgently desire freedom of trade and do not want to restrict
the import of their products with tariffs of any kind. — Should the tariffs remain, they would no longer be able to eradicate the factories of the continent, which the decree of Napoleon, whose genius so correctly recognised the true cause of the difference in the industrial conditions of the continent in comparison with England, had brought about, or if not eradicate at least paralyse them in such a way that their commercial and industrial egotism would continue to enjoy the fruits of its meditations at the expense of the gradually impoverished and exhausted nations. — What England already so severely oppresses, albeit in part still secretly, are her workers' associations. One need only have been in the factory towns of England and visited this class of society in its low, dark dwellings, and then compare the enormous disparity which the luxury of a comparatively small part of the nation displays to the eye, to arrive at the conclusion that there is nothing in the world which does not have its cause, and that the above phenomena, which may possibly become more glaring in time, or at any rate may continue for some time, are only the burgeoning effects of deep-seated and long-standing causes.

As a result of the aforementioned means employed by it, England produces, in a word, excessively. If it cannot generate profit in this or that way at the expense of other nations, the immediate consequence will be that precisely a part of its poorest inhabitants,
that is, the factory workers, will be forced to sit on their hands and thus become a burden to the country. Until then, so it seems, the governments of the continent are still very much on their guard to accept the friendly invitation of the English for free trade as quickly and willingly as the latter would like, given the state of affairs. What Switzerland will do remains to be seen. What we should do, however, can soon be decided upon quiet and uninterested examination. In conclusion, for those who are so fond of giving their money to strangers, I leave the following remarks made to me by the late King Frederick of Würtemberg, so full of wit and profoundly aware of the duties of a regent, when in the summer of 1814, during my stay in Stuttgart, I was summoned to his pleasure palace "Mon Repos" near Ludwigsburg, in a conversation lasting two hours on various subjects concerning the production and consumption of various articles in my own country, or their procurement more cheaply from abroad. He said (verbatim, I immediately wrote it down in my diary) speaking in reference to rifles: "I am taxed for making rifles for my military in my factory in Oberndorf, each piece of which costs me 6 new Thaler, while I could get them from Liège or Birmingham for a Louis d'or. However, a monarch or a government cannot calculate like an individual. Though it is also advantageous for them if savings can be made,
if I pay a Louis d'or to England, it is lost forever. If I pay 6 Thaler for a rifle that is made in my own country, 3 go back into my pocket," he said, tapping his hand on his vest pocket.

There is still much left to be said which relates more to particularities, but this little may be regarded here as the reverse side of what the friends of free trade parade before the public, and apply to what should be done in Switzerland. I believe that we, as one of the smallest and youngest states, for it is only through the Confederation that we have become oneThe adoption of the new Federal Constitution of 1848 transformed Switzerland from a confederation into a federal state., according to the new unified theory, should wait to see what larger established governments will do in the discussed matters and, instead, come to a better understanding with our closest neighbours, from whom we could expect more favourable responses in any case, as the need for commerce is mutual, than from a distant country whose trade policy ultimately proceeds only from itself and its own advantage and is likewise concentrated there.

The second matter about which I still have something to say concerns the lithograph appended to these notes. I regarded it as superfluous to describe the dimensions of the Crystal Palace, though it was the main reason for my journey, not only because this had been done much earlier in a number of newspapers, etc.,
but also because I was convinced that a mere indication of the length and width of this marvellous building, in feet or "klafter", could hardly give anyone a clear idea of its extent or size, unless some sort of visualization were to be added to it, and so I had the idea, which gave me a great deal of pleasure from the moment it arose: What if instead of these specifications, as if by magic, the Crystal Palace were to be constructed above Schaffhausen. I placed the floor plan of the former, reduced to the same scale, on top of the plan of the city, so that one could then see how many streets and public spaces it would cover in length and width, it is useful to achieve the aforementioned purpose to a degreeErratum from the first edition.. Through the kindness of Mr. Peyer, I received the scaled-down plan of our city, which his meritorious and highly respected father had drawn up with great diligence.

To this plan I have superimposed, as I said, the floor plan of the exhibition building and only remark for those who have not read any description of this building that in its length, which is 1851 English feet, it would extend all the way from the Schwabenthor down to the Rhine and, with itsErratum from the first edition. width of 408 feet, would cover several of our main streets, squares and churches. May the execution of this idea, though imperfect, be well received.

The Author.
Schaffhausen, 21 December 1852.
